revision.text:
{{Generalize|date=September 2011}}[[File:Iron Oxide Cycle.svg|thumb|Simplified diagram of the iron oxide cycle]] The '''iron oxide cycle''' (Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>/FeO) is the original two-step [[thermochemical cycle]] proposed for use for [[hydrogen production]].<ref>[http://www.hydrogen.energy.gov/pdfs/review06/pd_10_weimer.pdf Project PD10]</ref> It is based on the reduction and subsequent oxidation of [[iron]] ions, particularly the reduction and oxidation from Fe<sup>3+</sup> to Fe<sup>2+</sup>. The [[Allotropes of iron|ferrites]], or iron oxide, begins in the form of a [[Spinel group|spinel]] and depending on the reaction conditions, dopant metals and support material forms either [[Wüstite]]s or different spinels.
==Process description== The thermochemical two-step [[water splitting]] process uses two [[redox]] steps. The steps of solar hydrogen production by iron based two-step cycle are:
(1) M(II)Fe<sub>2</sub>(III)O<sub>4</sub> → M(II)O + 2Fe(II)O + ½O<sub>2</sub> (Reduction)
(2) M(II)O + 2Fe(II)O + H<sub>2</sub>O → M(II)Fe<sub>2</sub>(III)O<sub>4</sub> + H<sub>2</sub> (Oxidation)
Where M can by any number of metals, often Fe itself, [[Cobalt|Co]], [[Nickel|Ni]], [[Manganese|Mn]], [[Zinc|Zn]] or [[alloy|mixtures]] thereof.
The endothermic reduction step (1) is carried out at high temperatures greater than 1400 <sup>o</sup>C, though the "[[Hercynite]] cycle" is capable of temperatures as low as 1200 <sup>o</sup>C. The oxidative water splitting step (2) occurs at a lower ~1000 <sup>o</sup>C temperature which produces the original ferrite material in addition to hydrogen gas. The temperature level is realized by using geothermal heat from [[magma]]<ref>[http://energy.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/Analysis_of_Geothermally_Produced_Hydrogen_BigIsland.pdf Sentech 2008-Analysis of geothermally produced hydrogen on the big island of Hawaii]</ref> or a [[solar power tower]] and a set of [[heliostat]]s to collect the [[solar thermal energy]].
==Hercynite cycle == Like the traditional iron oxide cycle, the hercynite is based on the oxidation and reduction of iron atoms. However unlike the traditional cycle, the ferrite material reacts with a second metal oxide, [[aluminum oxide]], rather than simply decomposing. The reactions take place via the following two reactions:
(1) M(II)Fe<sub>2</sub>(III)O<sub>4</sub> + 3Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> → M(II)Al<sub>2</sub>(III)O<sub>4</sub> + 2Fe(II)Al<sub>2</sub>(III)O<sub>4</sub> + ½O<sub>2</sub> (Reduction)
(2) M(II)Al<sub>2</sub>(III)O<sub>4</sub> + 2Fe(II)Al<sub>2</sub>(III)O<sub>4</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O → M(II)Fe<sub>2</sub>(III)O<sub>4</sub> + 3Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> + H<sub>2</sub> (Oxidation)
The reduction step of the hercynite reaction takes place at temperature ~ 200 <sup>o</sup>C lower than the traditional water splitting cycle (1200 <sup>o</sup>C).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sheffe|first=Jonathan|author2=Jianhua Li |author3=Alan W. Weimer |title=A spinel ferrite/hercynite water-splitting redox cycle|journal=International Journal of Hydrogen Energy|year=2010|volume=35|issue=8|pages=3333–3340|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0360319910002387|doi=10.1016/j.ijhydene.2010.01.140}}</ref> This leads to lower radiation losses, which scale as temperature to the fourth power.
==Advantages and Disadvantages== The advantages of the ferrite cycles are: they have lower reduction temperatures than other 2-step systems, no metallic gasses are produced, high specific H<sub>2</sub> production capacity, non-toxicity of the elements used and abundance of the constituent elements.
The disadvantages of the ferrite cycles are: similar reduction and melting temperature of the spinels (except for the hercynite cycle as aluminates have very high melting temperatures), and slow rates of the oxidation, or [[water splitting]], reaction.
==See also== * [[Cerium(IV) oxide-cerium(III) oxide cycle]] * [[Copper-chlorine cycle]] * [[Hybrid sulfur cycle]] * [[Hydrosol-2]] * [[Sulfur-iodine cycle]] * [[Zinc zinc-oxide cycle]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://solar.web.psi.ch/data/closedProjects/ Solar hydrogen from iron oxide based thermochemical cycles]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Iron Oxide Cycle}} [[Category:Chemical reactions]] [[Category:Hydrogen production]]

Later, a [[hedge fund]] manager, and [[private security contractor]] | signature = | signature_size= | signature_alt = | website = | module = }} [[Lieutenant-General]] '''Javed Nasir''' ([[Urdu language|Urdu:]] جاويد ناصر;b. 1936{{rp|112}}) {{small|[[Hilal-e-Imtiaz|HI(M)]], [[Sitara-e-Basalat|SBt]], [[Pakistan Engineering Council|PEC]]}}), is a retired [[engineering officer]] in the [[Pakistan Army Corps of Engineers]], who served as the [[:Category:Directors General of Inter-Services Intelligence|Director-General]] of the [[Directorate for Inter-Services Intelligence|Inter-Services Intelligence]] (ISI), appointed on 14 March 1992 until being forcefully removed from this assignment on 13 May 1993. An educator and engineer by profession, Nasir gained national prominence as his role of bringing the [[Peshawar Seven|unscattered mass]] of [[Afghan mujahideen|Afghan Mujahideen]] to agree to the [[Peshawar Accord|power-sharing formula]] to form [[Afghan government|Afghan administration]] under President [[Sibghatullah Mojaddedi|Mojaddedi]] in Afghanistan in 1992–93. Later, he played an influential and decisive role in the [[Bosnian war]] when he oversaw the [[ISI activities in Bosnia|covert military intelligence]] program to support the [[Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnian Army]] against the [[Republika Srpska (1991–95)|Serbs]], while airlifting the thousands of [[Bosnians in Pakistan|Bosnian refugees]] in Pakistan. ==Biography== Javed Nasir was born in [[Lahore]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]] in [[British Indian Empire|India]] in 1936,{{rp|112}}{{rp|834}} and is of the [[Kashmiri people|Kashmiri descent]].{{cite book|last1=Sirrs|first1=Owen L.|title=Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence Directorate: Covert Action and Internal Operations|date=2016|publisher=Routledge|location=New York City|isbn=9781317196099|pages=305|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_S-TDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA148&dq=Javed+Nasir+kashmiri+origin#v=onepage&q=Javed%20Nasir%20kashmiri%20origin&f=false|accessdate=13 November 2017|language=en|format=googlebooks|chapter={{small|The Bearded General}}}}{{rp|148}}{{cite book|last1=Joshi|first1=P. C.|title=Main Intelligence Outfits Of Pakistan|date=2008|publisher=Anmol Publications Pvt. Limited|location=New Delhi, India|isbn=9788126135509|pages=435|url=https://books.google.com/?id=B3zfAAAAMAAJ&dq=javed+nasir+nawaz+mna&q=MNA|accessdate=14 November 2017|language=en}}{{rp|169}} After his [[Matriculation in Pakistan|matriculation]] from local school in Lahore, Nasir joined the [[Pakistan Army]] and entered in the [[Pakistan Military Academy]] at [[Kakul]] in 1953.{{cite book|last1=Sehgal|first1=Ikram ul-Majeed|title=Defence Journal|date=1998|publisher=Ikram ul-Majeed Sehgal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=MozfAAAAMAAJ&q=JAVED+NASIR+1958&dq=JAVED+NASIR+1958 |page=26 |accessdate=13 November 2017|language=en}} He decided to attend the [[Military College of Engineering (Pakistan)|Military College of Engineering]] at [[Risalpur]] in [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa]], and graduated with [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] with [[BSc (Hons)|Honors]] in civil engineering in 1958. He gained [[Commissioned officer|commissioned]] as [[Second Lieutenant|2nd-Lt.]] in the [[Corps of Engineers, Pakistan Army|Corps of Engineers]] of the [[Pakistan Army]] where his career is mostly spent.{{cite web|last1=Nasir|first1=Lt-Gen. Javed|title=Ghauri and its Aftermath|url=http://www.defencejournal.com/may98/ghauri_aftermath.htm|website=www.defencejournal.com|publisher=Defence Journal|accessdate=13 November 2017|location=Islamabad, Pakistan|language=en-pk|date=May 1998}} In 1967, Nasir qualified as a [[Regulation and licensure in engineering|licensed]] [[Professional engineering|professional engineer]] (PE) by the [[Pakistan Engineering Council]] (PEC).{{rp|834}} He was known to have served in the [[Combat Engineering|combat engineering]] [[Military engineering vehicle|formations]] during the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965|second war]] with India in 1965 as [[Captain (Army)|army captain]], and later served in the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|western front]] of the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|third war]] with India in 1971 as major.{{cite book|last1=Bhattacharya|first1=Brigadier Samir|title=Nothing But!|date=2014|publisher=Partridge Publishing|location=London, UK|isbn=9781482817324|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/?id=7GrAAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA372&dq=Brig+JAVED+NASIR#v=onepage&q=Brig%20JAVED%20NASIR&f=false |pages=372–373|accessdate=13 November 2017|language=en-uk|format=googlebooks}}{{cite book|title=Journal of the Institution of Engineers Pakistan|date=1967|publisher=Institution of Engineers, Pakistan|url=https://books.google.com/?id=r1VQAAAAYAAJ&dq=javed+nasir+engineer+in+chief&q=javed+nasir+|accessdate=13 November 2017|language=en}}{{rp|834}} After the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|third war]] with India in 1971, [[Major|Maj.]] Nasir went to Australia where he attended and graduated in [[Staff (military)|staff course]] from the [[Australian Army Staff College]].{{cite book|last1=Sehgal|first1=Ikram ul-Majeed|title=Defence Journal|date=2000|publisher=Ikram ul-Majeed Sehgal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=mZHfAAAAMAAJ&dq=JAVED+NASIR+australia&q=+australia |page=19 |accessdate=13 November 2017|language=en}} In 1980s, he was sent to attend the [[National Defence University, Pakistan|National Defence University]] (NDU) in [[Islamabad]], and graduated with [[Master of Science|MSc]] in [[Strategic studies]]. In 1983–90, [[Major-General]] Nasir joined the faculty of the [[War college|Armed Forces War College]] of the [[National Defense University, Islamabad|National Defense University]] (NDU), which he instructed courses on [[war studies]] for seven years, eventually promoted as [[Full Professor|chief instructor]].{{cite book|last1=Scherer|first1=John L.|title=China Facts & Figures Annual|date=1985|publisher=Academic International Press|url=https://books.google.com/?id=5keFAAAAIAAJ&q=major+general+Javed+Nasir&dq=major+general+Javed+Nasir |page=62 |accessdate=13 November 2017|language=en}}{{cite book|title=Daily Report: Asia & Pacific|date=1986|publisher=The Service|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nBP6JoY1eoUC&dq=major+general+Javed+Nasir&q=Javed+Nasir |page=59 |language=en}} In the [[Pakistani military|military circles]], [[Major-General|Maj-Gen.]] Nasir was described as a "[[Modern Islamic philosophy|moderate person]]" who [[Islamic revival|rediscovered]] the [[Wahhabi Islam|Islam]] in 1986 during the midst of the [[Soviet war in Afghanistan|Russian war]] in the neighboring [[Afghanistan]].{{rp|148–149}} In 1988, Maj-Gen. Nasir gained public fame when he was appointed as inspector-general of engineering formation that investigated the [[Ojhri Camp disaster|environmental disaster]] befall at the [[Ojhri Camp|military storage]] located in the [[Rawalpindi Cantonment]].{{cite web|last1=Nasir|first1=Javed|title=Gen Javed Nasir Karguzari of Ojhri Camp Incident جنرل جاوید ناصر کی اوجڑی کیمپ کارگزاری|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQH2GgWqc2I|website=www.youtube.com|publisher=Message TV|accessdate=13 November 2017|date=2 July 2017}} Against the United States, German and French military estimation, Maj-Gen. Nasir personally led his formation at the ground to clear out the entire storage containing the [[Chemical weapon|chemical]] and [[explosive material]]s, as well as the [[Stinger missile|missile ordnance]] in mere two weeks.{{rp|112–113}} In 1989, he was appointed as director-general of [[Frontier Works Organization]] (FWO) and supervised the civil construction of the [[Skardu Airport|Skardu International Airport]] that is {{convert|11944|ft|m}} [[above sea level]].{{rp|112}} On 24 September 1991, [[Major-General|Maj-Gen.]] Nasir was promoted as a [[Three-star general|three-star]] rank [[Pak Fauj|army general]], having appointed to command the [[Pakistan Army Corps of Engineers|Corps of Engineers]] as its [[Engineer-in-Chief (Pakistan Army)|Eng-in-C]] at the [[GHQ (Pakistan Army)|Army GHQ]] in [[Rawalpindi Cantonment|Rawalpindi]].{{cite news|last1=Cowasjee|first1=Ardeshir|authorlink1=Ardeshir Cowasjee|title=Three stars|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1072680|accessdate=13 November 2017|work=DAWN.COM|agency=Dawn Newspapers|publisher=Dawn Newspapers|date=12 January 2003|location=Karachi, Sindh, Pk|language=en-pk}} On 4 February 1992, [[Lieutenant-General]] Nasir was then posted as the chairman of the [[Pakistan Ordnance Factories]] at [[Wah, Pakistan|Wah]] in [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], Pakistan, until being appointed as the [[:Category:Directors General of Inter-Services Intelligence|Director-General]] of the [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] (ISI). ==Director of ISI (1992–93)== On 14 March 1992, Prime Minister [[Nawaz Sharif]] appointed [[Lieutenant-General|Lt-Gen]] Nasir as the [[:Category:Directors General of Inter-Services Intelligence|Director-General]] of the [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] (ISI) against the recommendations and wishes of General [[Asif Nawaz]], then-[[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|chief of army staff]] (COAS).{{cite book|title=Journal of the United Service Institution of India|date=2001|publisher=United Service Institution of India. |page=366 |language=en}} The appointment was seen a political motive for Prime Minister [[Nawaz Sharif]] since General Nasir had no experience in the [[intelligence gathering network]] and was virtually a ghost in country's [[Pakistani intelligence community|intelligence community]].{{cite book|last1=Arif|first1=Khalid Mahmud|authorlink1=Khalid Mahmud Arif |year=2001 |title=Khaki Shadows: Pakistan 1947-1997 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Karachi, Pakistan |isbn=9780195793963 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Nf0vAQAAIAAJ&dq=nawaz+javed+nasir&q=+javed+nasir |pages=365–366 |accessdate=13 November 2017|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Cloughley|first1=Brian|title=War, Coups & Terror: Pakistan's Army in Years of Turmoil|date=2008|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing Inc.|isbn=9781602396982|edition=2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=JBUAwavfcDkC&pg=PA76&dq=nawaz+javed+nasir#v=onepage&q=nawaz%20javed%20nasir&f=false |page=76 |accessdate=13 November 2017|language=en}} At that time, [[Nawaz Sharif|Prime Minister Sharif]] had family relations with Lt-Gen. Nasir Javed, and knew him very well.{{rp|169}} In the military, he was of the view of [[Anti-American sentiment in Pakistan|anti-American sentiments]], accusing the United States of using the [[Islam]] for political reasons and against [[Soviet Union|Russians]] in Europe, which further complicated the [[United States Pakistan relations|foreign relations]] between [[United States and Pakistan|two nations]].{{rp|14}} He also limited the cooperation between the [[ISI (Pakistan)|ISI]] and [[American CIA|CIA]] to fight against the [[War on Terror|global terrorism]], thwarting any joint efforts to fight against extremism.{{cite book|last1=Sehgal|first1=Ikram ul-Majeed|title=Defence Journal|date=2003|publisher=Ikram ul-Majeed Sehgal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=uqbfAAAAMAAJ&q=javed+nasir+USA&dq=javed+nasir+USA |page=14 |accessdate=13 November 2017|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Inc|first1=IBP|title=Pakistan Intelligence, Security Activities and Operations Handbook - Strategic Information and Developments|date=2009|publisher=Lulu.com|isbn=9781438737225|url=https://books.google.com/?id=F40RCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA52&dq=javed+nasir+USA#v=onepage&q=javed%20nasir%20USA&f=false|page=52|accessdate=13 November 2017|language=en}} Though, he did help the US to relocate and retrieve the missing [[Operation MIAS|guided missiles]] from [[Afghanistan]] based on a mutual understanding of such weapons may have fall in wrong hands.{{cite web|last1=Ahmad|first1=Iftikhar|title=DG ISI Nasir in Jawab Deh|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bE-GGoF7A1Q|website=www.youtube.com|publisher=Geo News Jawab Deh|accessdate=15 November 2017|location=Islamabad, Pakistan|language=ur|date=25 November 2008}} It was during this time when ISI had been running an intensified support for [[Kashmiri insurgency|insurgency]] in [[Indian-occupied Jammu and Kashmir|Indian Kashmir]].{{cite book|last1=Datta|first1=S. K.|title=Inside ISI: The Story and Involvement of the ISI, Afghan Jihad, Taliban, Al-Qaeda, 9/11, Osama Bin Laden, 26/11 and the Future of Al-Qaeda~|date=2014|publisher=Vij Books India Pvt Ltd.|isbn=9789382652595|url=https://books.google.com/?id=bgmqCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA6&dq=javed+nasir+isi#v=onepage&q=javed%20nasir%20isi&f=false |page=6 |accessdate=13 November 2017|language=en}} In spite of his seniority in the military, Nasir was overlooked, and was never considered for the promotion of the [[Four star rank|four-star]] rank and appointment by the government during the appointmentment process for the command of the [[Pakistan Army|Army]], the [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Army Staff]] (COAS). [[Lieutenant-General|Lt-Gen]] Nasir was among the five senior and superseding army generals when the junior-most [[Lieutenant-General|Lt-Gen]] [[Abdul Waheed Kakar]] was elevated to the four-star rank and promotion to command the army. ===Peshawar Accord and Mojaddedi administration=== {{Main|History of Afghanistan (1992–present)|Peshawar Accord}} On April 1992, [[Lieutenant-General|Lt-Gen.]] Nasir became an international figure when he played major role in amalgamating the [[Peshawar Seven|unscattered]] [[Afghan mujahideen]] groups when the [[Peshawar Accord|power-sharing formula]] was drafted. Due to his [[religiosity]], Nasir used his persuasive power and motivational talks to agree to [[Peshawar Accord|power-sharing formula]] and, witnessed to have successfully establishing an [[Afghan government|Afghan administration]] under cleric President [[Sibghatullah Mojaddedi]] in [[Kabul]]. ===Bosnian war=== {{see also|Inter-Services Intelligence activities in Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnian mujahideen|Bosnians in Pakistan}} In the military and political circles, Nasir was had reputation to be a practising Muslim who would not compromise on the interests of Islam and Pakistan. In 1992–93, Nasir defied the UN arms embargo placed on [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] when he successfully airlifted the [[Pakistan Ordnance Factories|POF]]'s sophisticated anti-tank guided missiles, which ultimately turned the tide in favour of Bosnian Muslims and forced the Serbs to life the siege much to the annoyance of the [[United States government|U.S. government]].{{cite news|url=http://www.satribune.com/archives/dec23_29_02/P1_bosniastory.htm |title=Ex-ISI Chief Reveals Secret Missile Shipments to Bosnia defying UN Embargo |date=23 December 2002 |accessdate=1 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108074722/http://www.satribune.com/archives/dec23_29_02/P1_bosniastory.htm |archivedate= 8 January 2010 |df= }} While airlifting sophisticated anti-tank guided missiles to Bosnian Muslims, he pushed the [[Government of Pakistan]] to allow the [[Bosnians in Pakistan|Bosnian immigrationto]] Pakistan.{{cite book|last=Sareen|first=Sushant|title=The jihad factory: Pakistan's Islamic revolution in the making|publisher=Har-Anand Publications|year=2005|pages=352|isbn=978-81-241-1075-1}} In 2011, the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] demanded the custody of the former ISI director for his alleged support of the [[Inter-Services Intelligence activities in Bosnia and Herzegovina]] to Muslim fighters of Bosnia against the Serbian army in the 1990s, the Government of Pakistan has refused to hand Nasir to the UN tribunal, citing poor health. ===Removal from the ISI=== In 1993, Lt-Gen. Nasir's zealous religiosity and maverick actions became embarrassing for the [[Pakistani military]], in which, the [[Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee|Chairman joint chiefs]] General [[Shamim Alam Khan|Shamim Allam]] had completely lost the control of the [[ISI (Pakistan)|ISI]] when the agency was running under Nasir's command.{{cite book|last1=Hussain|first1=Zahid|authorlink1=Zahid Hussain (journalist)|title=Frontline Pakistan: The Path to Catastrophe and the Killing of Benazir Bhutto|date=2008|publisher=Penguin Books, Canada|location=Ottawa, Canada|isbn=9780143064794|pages=220|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ma5Xx4hNF0wC&pg=PA26&dq=Javed+Nasir+embarrassment#v=onepage&q=Javed%20Nasir%20embarrassment&f=false|accessdate=15 November 2017|language=en-pk|format=googlebooks|chapter={{small|Pakistan's unholy alliance""}}}}{{rp|26}} General [[Abdul Waheed Kakar]], the [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|army chief]] at that time, had been at odds with Lt-Gen. Nasir due to his preaching of Islamic tradition in the military. In the views of senior military officers in the [[Pakistani military]] and the civilian officials of the [[Ministry of Defence Pakistan|Ministry of Defence]], Lt-Gen. Nasir was often a figure of fun whose intellect was far from being as outstanding as his white beard.{{cite book|last1=Cloughley|first1=Brian|title=War, Coups and Terror: Pakistan's Army in Years of Turmoil|date=2009|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing, Inc.|isbn=9781626368682|url=https://books.google.com/?id=XhMnAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT105&dq=Javed+Nasir+fired#v=onepage&q=Javed%20Nasir%20fired&f=false |page=contents |accessdate=15 November 2017|language=en}} During this time, the [[Indian government]] led by Prime Minister [[P. V. Narasimha Rao]] leveled several accusations on him of supporting the [[Khalistan movement]], the [[Indian Mafia]] and [[Dawood Ibrahim]]– the accusations he swiftly denied in 2008.{{rp|26–27}} At home, Nasir begin facing accusation from [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] politicians of supporting the conservative Islamic agenda in the country. In 1993, the United States formally registered their complaints to Pakistan when U.S. secretary of State [[James Baker]] written a memo to Prime Minister Sharif of putting his country on a terror watch list and was in danger of being listed as terror-supporting nation.{{rp|27–28}} Responding to the complain, Prime Minister Sharif used diplomacy when he sent his [[Foreign Secretary (Pakistan)|Foreign Secretary]] [[Shahryar Khan]] and [[Pakistani senators|Pakistan Senator]] [[Akram Zaki]] to United States of assuring Pakistan's policy of not supporting the militancy in the region.{{rp|27–28}} During this time, several [[Arab countries]] such as [[Egypt]], [[Tunisia]], [[Algeria]], and the [[Philippines]], lodged a strong protest against Nasir of supporting the radical movements in their respected countries.{{cite book|last1=Sareen|first1=Sushant|title=The Jihad Factory: Pakistan's Islamic Revolution in the Making|date=2005|publisher=Har-Anand Publications|location=New Delhi|isbn=9788124110751|pages=216|url=https://books.google.com/?id=uSxZhFenUusC&pg=PA152&dq=Javed+Nasir+arab+countries#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=15 November 2017|language=en}}{{rp|152}}{{cite news|last1=Lodhi, PhD|first1=Dr. Maleeha|title=Removal of Javed Nasir|work=The Newsline|agency=The Newsline|publisher=Dr. Maleeha Lodhi, The Newsline|date=14 May 1993|location=Islamabad, Pakistan|language=en-pk}} Following the resignations of Prime Minister Sharif and President [[Ghulam Ishaq Khan|G.I. Khan]] on 18 July 1993, the caretaker Prime Minister [[Moeenuddin Ahmad Qureshi|M.A. Qureshi]] fired and sacked Nasir from the directorship of the ISI, and [[Acting President of Pakistan|Acting President]] [[Wasim Sajjad]] approved his premature retirement from his [[Commissioned officer|military commission]] effective from on 13 May 1993{{rp|170}}— he only led the ISI for 13 months.{{cite book|title=Asian Bulletin|date=1993|publisher=APACL Publications|url=https://books.google.com/?id=lkknAAAAMAAJ&dq=Javed+Nasir+arab+countries&q=Javed+Nasir |page=44 |accessdate=15 November 2017|language=en}} Upon his firing, the new DG ISI, [[Javed Ashraf Qazi|J.A. Qazi]] eventually led the massive arrests of thousands of [[Arab Afghan]]s and forced the [[al-Qaeda]] to relocate itself in [[Afghanistan]] permanently.{{cite book|last1=Scott|first1=Peter Dale|title=The Road to 9/11: Wealth, Empire, and the Future of America|date=2007|publisher=University of California Press|location=Palo Alto, Ca.|isbn=9780520929944|pages=400|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/?id=op39ymd2um0C&pg=PA146&dq=Javed+Nasir+fired#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=15 November 2017|language=en|format=google books|chapter=The Afghan Arabs after 1990}}{{rp|147–149}} Expulsion from Pakistan, many escaped to [[Bosnia]] to [[Foreign fighters in the Bosnian War|participate in the war]].{{rp|149}} According to many political commentators and journalists, Nasir's firing from ISI was not at the behest of the United States but, it was the friendly [[Arab world|Arab countries]]' protests and pressure at the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]] (OIC) that resulted in his departure from ISI and the retirement from his 40-year long [[Military service|service]] with the military.{{cite book|last1=Joshi|first1=P.C.|title=Main intelligence outfits of Pakistan|date=2008|publisher=Anmol Publications|location=New Delhi|isbn=9788126135509|language=en}}{{rp|170}} ==Later life== After his premature retirement, Nasir became a [[Islamic missionary activity|missionary]] for a [[Tablighi Jamaat]], and went to the [[Corporate sector of Pakistan|private sector]] when he managed and chaired the [[private equity]] firm and [[hedge fund]], the Evacuee Trust Property Board (ETPB), when he was appointed on 14 July 1997 for a two-year contract.{{rp|171}}{{cite book|last1=Sehri|first1=Inam|title=Judges and Generals of Pakistan Volume - I|date=2012|publisher=Grosvenor House Publishing|location=Lahore, Pakistan|isbn=9781781480434|edition=1|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gzllAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT326&dq=javed+nasir+Evacuee+Property#v=onepage&q=javed%20nasir%20Evacuee%20Property&f=false |page=contents|accessdate=15 November 2017|language=en|format=google books}} In 1998, he was appointed as chairman of [[Pakistan Sikh Gurdwara Prabandhak Committee|Sikh Gurdwara Prabandhak Committee]], a [[Sikhism in Pakistan|pro-Sikhism]] organization in Pakistan promoting the religious activities of [[Sikhism]].{{cite book|last1=Sharma|first1=D. P.|title=The New Terrorism: Islamist International|date=2005|publisher=APH Publishing|isbn=9788176487993|url=https://books.google.com/?id=9rBpDinDjI8C&pg=PA408&dq=Javed+Nasir+shahbaz+sharif#v=onepage&q=Javed%20Nasir%20shahbaz%20sharif&f=false|accessdate=15 November 2017|language=en}}{{rp|408}} On October 1998, Prime Minister Sharif appointed him as his intelligence adviser but this appointment remained for short period of time.{{rp|408}} For sometimes, he served on the security details as head of security for the [[Sharif family]], but the [[Pakistan Muslim League (N)|PML(N)]]'s lawmakers and Sharif family cut off their links and distance themselves from Nasir after the [[September 11 attacks|9/11 terrorist attacks]] in the United States in 2001.{{cite news|last1=Special reporter|first1=SP|title=PMLN government can't control terrorism: Ex-DG ISI Khawaja Javed Nasir|url=https://www.express.com.pk/epaper/PoPupwindow.aspx?newsID=1101969793&Issue=NP_LHE&Date=20130924|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=www.express.com.pk|agency=Daily Express News Story|publisher=Daily Express News Story|date=9 September 2013|location=Faisalabad, Pakistan|language=ur}} In 2002–03, Nasir filed a lawsuit at the [[Anti Terrorism Court of Pakistan|Anti Terrorism Court]] against the media corporations: the ''[[Daily Jang]]'', and the [[The News International|''News International'']], for [[character defamation]] when investigatives articles published on him on the monetary embezzlement when he managed the private hedge fund in Lahore.{{cite web|title=Petition filed by Lt Gen (Retd) Javed Nasir, Former Director General, Inter Services Intelligence, Pakistan, before the Anti Terrorism Court, Lahore|url=http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/pakistan/document/papers/petition.htm|website=www.satp.org|accessdate=15 November 2017}} In 2008, he appeared on the [[Geo News]] and denied any allegations of terror supporting that was leveled on him during his time as Director ISI, when interviewed by [[Iftikhar Ahmad (journalist)|Iftikhar Ahmad]]. At this detailed and hour-long interview, he was of the view of [[9/11 conspiracy theories (Jews and Zionists)|9/11 was an inside job]], and maintained on his stance on the suppressing of the [[Free energy suppression conspiracy theory|free-energy]] by the [[US Government|U.S.]] and [[Pakistan Government]]. In 2011, the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia|International Criminal Tribunal]] for the former [[Yugoslavia]] demanded the custody of the Nasir for his alleged authorization of the [[Inter-Services Intelligence activities in Bosnia and Herzegovina|covert program to support]] to the [[Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnian Army]] against the Serbian army in the 1990s, the Government of Pakistan refused to hand Nasir to the UN tribunal, citing poor health and [[Amnesia|memory loss]] due to a road accident.{{cite news|last1=Butt|first1=Qaiser|title=Islamabad refuses to hand over ex-ISI chief to Bosnia tribunal - The Express Tribune|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/256199/islamabad-refuses-to-hand-over-ex-isi-chief-to-bosnia-tribunal/|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=The Express Tribune|agency=The Express Tribune|publisher=The Express Tribune, 2011|date=20 September 2011}} In 2013, Nasir reportedly spoke against Afghan Taliban and the terrorism at the Supreme Court convention, and criticised the [[Afghan Taliban|Taliban]] as an armed violent group and criticised them of supporting the violent terrorism for their cause, in a response to the [[Peshawar church bombing|church bombing]]. ==See also== * [[Bosnian war]] * [[History of the United States (1991–2008)]] * [[Conservatism in Pakistan]] * [[Blowback (intelligence)]] * [[Flip-flop (politics)|Flip-flop]] * [[History of Afghanistan (1992–present)]] * [[India and state-sponsored terrorism]] * [[Foreign policy of Pakistan]] ** [[Islamic conservatism]] ** [[Sikhism in Pakistan]] ** ''[[Muslim Ummah]]'' ** [[Pakistan and state-sponsored terrorism]] ** [[Pakistan military presence in other countries]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.dawn.com/weekly/cowas/20030112.htm Article about Javed Nasir by Ardeshir Cowasjee] * [http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=story_25-8-2002_pg3_1 Editorial about Gen Nasir fleeing the country] * [http://www.cooperativeresearch.org/entity.jsp?entity=javed_nasir_1 Lt. Gen. testifies Pakistani Vessel Shipping Arms to Bosnia] * [http://www.dailyexcelsior.com/02aug26/inter.htm#3 Pak Govt puts off inquiry against ex-ISI chief] * http://www.tribuneindia.com/2001/20010417/main2.htm * http://www.organiser.org/09apr2000/lahore.html * http://www.sikhtimes.com/news_060705a.html * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6D_nfdxIqug Interview with Geo TV] {{S-start}} {{S-mil}} {{S-bef|before=[[Asad Durrani]]}} {{S-ttl|title=Director General of the [[Inter-Services Intelligence]]|years=1992–1993}} {{S-aft|after=[[Javed Ashraf Qazi]]}} {{end}} {{Military of Pakistan}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nasir, Javed}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:Kashmiri people]] [[Category:People from Lahore]] [[Category:Pakistan Military Academy alumni]] [[Category:Pakistani engineers]] [[Category:Pakistani civil engineers]] [[Category:Engineers from Lahore]] [[Category:Pakistani expatriates in Australia]] [[Category:Pakistani military engineers]] [[Category:National Defence University, Pakistan alumni]] [[Category:National Defence University, Pakistan faculty]] [[Category:Pakistani generals]] [[Category:Pakistani Sunni Muslims]] [[Category:Directors General of Inter-Services Intelligence]] [[Category:Military personnel of the Bosnian War]] [[Category:Pakistani Islamists]] [[Category:Kashmiri Islamists]] [[Category:Tablighi Jamaat]] [[Category:Muslim missionaries]] [[Category:Sikhism in Pakistan]] [[Category:Pakistani Muslim activists]] [[Category:People acquitted by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] [[Category:Conspiracy theorists]] [[Category:9/11 conspiracy theorists]] [[Category:Free energy conspiracy theorists]] [[Category:Pakistani corporate directors]] [[Category:People with amnesia]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Bamboo species]]; added [[Category:Bamboo]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''[[Bamboo]]''' {{Audio|En-us-bamboo.ogg|listen}} is a group of [[wood]]y [[perennial plant|perennial]] [[grass]]es in the [[true grass]] family [[Poaceae]], which is a large family with over 10,000 species. In the tribe ''[[Bambuseae]]'' also known as bamboo, there are 91 [[genera]] and over 1,000 [[species]]. The size of bamboo varies from small annuals to giant timber bamboo. Bamboo evolved only 30 to 40 million years ago, after the demise of the dinosaurs. Bamboo is the fastest-growing woody plant in the world. It can grow up to 91–122 centimetres/day (3.8-5.0 centimetres/hr).<ref>Armstrong, W.P. [http://waynesword.palomar.edu/ecoph39.htm "Bamboo: Remarkable Giant Grasses".] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027064422/http://waynesword.palomar.edu/ecoph39.htm |date=2014-10-27 }} Wayne's Word. Accessed January 2013.</ref>
Bamboo species can be divided into clumpers and runners. Clumpers grow from the soil in a slowly expanding tuft. Runners send underground rhizomes to produce shoots several metres from the parent plant.<ref>[http://www.bamboo.org/GeneralInfoPages/RunnersAndClumpers.html American Bamboo Society]</ref>
All Chinese names for bamboo contain the character "[[竹]]". This character by itself simply means bamboo, however it enters into hundreds of other words and phrases. "Every day our written language reminds us of the antiquity of China's partnership with bamboo." (Dr. W. Y. Hsiung). This character, pronounced ''zhu'' depicts two leafed twigs of bamboo. The radical 竹 also indicates "sense".<ref>National Geographic October 1980</ref>

revision.comment: Adding a reference for organic luminophores.
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=August 2017}} A '''luminophore''' is an [[atom]] or [[functional group]] in a [[chemical compound]] that is responsible for its [[luminescence|luminescent]] properties.<ref name="Kricka2003"/> Luminophores can be either organic<ref name="OrganicLuminophores"/> or inorganic.
Luminophores can be further classified as [[fluorophore]]s or [[phosphor]]s, depending on the nature of the [[excited state]] responsible for the emission of [[photon]]s. However, some luminophores cannot be classified as being exclusively fluorophores or phosphors. Examples include [[transition-metal]] complexes such as [[tris(bipyridine)ruthenium(II) chloride]], whose luminescence comes from an excited (nominally triplet) metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) state, which is not a true triplet state in the strict sense of the definition; and colloidal [[quantum dots]], whose emissive state does not have either a purely singlet or triplet spin.
Most luminophores consist of [[conjugated system|conjugated π systems]] or transition-metal complexes. There are also purely inorganic luminophores, such as [[zinc sulfide]] doped with [[rare-earth metal]] ions, rare-earth metal oxysulfides doped with other rare-earth metal ions, [[yttrium oxide]] doped with rare-earth metal ions, [[zinc orthosilicate]] doped with manganese ions, etc. Luminophores can be observed in action in fluorescent lights, television screens, computer monitor screens, [[organic light-emitting diode]]s and [[bioluminescence]].
The correct, textbook terminology is ''luminophore'', not ''lumophore'', although the latter term has been frequently used in the chemical literature.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/705355252|title=Bioinorganic medicinal chemistry|date=2011|publisher=Wiley-VCH|others=Alessio, E. (Enzo)|isbn=9783527633104|location=Weinheim|oclc=705355252}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Chromophore]] * [[Fluorophore]] * [[Phosphor]]
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name="Kricka2003">{{Citation | first1 = Larry J. | last1 = Kricka | title = Optical Methods: A Guide to the "Escences" | publisher = American Association for Clinical Chemistry | page = 110 | year = 2003 | isbn = 1890883913 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=q8aV3mAJFZgC&pg=PA110 | postscript= . }}</ref> <ref name="OrganicLuminophores">{{Citation | first1 = Andrei | last1 = Dragan | title = Organic Luminophores | publisher = ChemPubSoc Europe | year = 2017 | url = https://www.chemistryviews.org/details/ezine/10483262/Organic_Luminophores.html | postscript= . }}</ref> }}
[[Category:Luminescence]] [[Category:Chemical compounds]]

Added free to read link in citations with [[WP:OABOT|OAbot]] #oabot
revision.text:
A '''microbial fuel cell''' ('''MFC'''), or '''biological fuel cell''', is a bio-[[electrochemical]] system<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.desal.2018.01.002 |title=Performance of microbial desalination cell for salt removal and energy generation using different catholyte solutions |journal=Desalination |volume=432 |pages=1–9 |year=2018 |last1=Ebrahimi |first1=Atieh |last2=Najafpour |first2=Ghasem D |last3=Yousefi Kebria |first3=Daryoush }}</ref> that drives an [[electric current]] by using [[bacteria]] and mimicking bacterial interactions found in [[nature]]. MFCs can be grouped into two general categories: mediated and unmediated. The first MFCs, demonstrated in the early 20th century, used a mediator: a chemical that transfers electrons from the bacteria in the cell to the anode. Unmediated MFCs emerged in the 1970s; in this type of MFC the bacteria typically have electrochemically active [[redox]] [[protein]]s such as [[cytochromes]] on their outer membrane that can transfer electrons directly to the anode.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.3389/fchem.2014.00079 |title=Emerging electrochemical energy conversion and storage technologies |journal=Frontiers in Chemistry |volume=2 |year=2014 |last1=Badwal |first1=Sukhvinder P. S |last2=Giddey |first2=Sarbjit S |last3=Munnings |first3=Christopher |last4=Bhatt |first4=Anand I |last5=Hollenkamp |first5=Anthony F }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.watres.2005.02.002 |pmid=15899266 |title=Electricity generation using membrane and salt bridge microbial fuel cells |journal=Water Research |volume=39 |issue=9 |pages=1675–86 |year=2005 |last1=Min |first1=Booki |last2=Cheng |first2=Shaoan |last3=Logan |first3=Bruce E }}</ref> In the 21st century MFCs started to find a commercial use in wastewater treatment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.microbialfuelcell.org/www/index.php/Applications/|title=MFC Pilot plant at the Fosters Brewery|accessdate=2013-03-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130415113407/http://www.microbialfuelcell.org/www/index.php/Applications/|archivedate=2013-04-15|df=}}</ref>
==History== The idea of using microbes to produce [[electricity]] was conceived in the early twentieth century. M. C. Potter initiated the subject in 1911.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1098/rspb.1911.0073 |jstor=80609 |title=Electrical Effects Accompanying the Decomposition of Organic Compounds |journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences |volume=84 |issue=571 |pages=260–76 |year=1911 |last1=Potter |first1=M. C }}</ref> Potter managed to generate electricity from ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'', but the work received little coverage. In 1931, Branet Cohen created microbial [[Half-cell|half]] [[fuel cell]]s that, when connected in series, were capable of producing over 35 volts with only a current of 2 [[milliamp]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cohen | first1 = B | year = 1931 | title = The Bacterial Culture as an Electrical Half-Cell | url = | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 21 | issue = | pages = 18–19 }}</ref>
A study by DelDuca et al. used hydrogen produced by the [[fermentation (biochemistry)|fermentation]] of glucose by ''[[Clostridium butyricum]]'' as the reactant at the anode of a hydrogen and air fuel cell. Though the cell functioned, it was unreliable owing to the unstable nature of hydrogen production by the micro-organisms.<ref>DelDuca, M. G., Friscoe, J. M. and Zurilla, R. W. (1963). Developments in Industrial Microbiology. ''American Institute of Biological Sciences'', 4, pp81–84.</ref> This issue was resolved by Suzuki et al. in 1976,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Karube | first1 = I. | last2 = Matasunga | first2 = T. | last3 = Suzuki | first3 = S. | last4 = Tsuru | first4 = S. | year = 1976 | title = Continuous hydrogen production by immobilized whole cels of ''Clostridium butyricum'' | url = | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 24 | issue = 2| pages = 338–343 | doi=10.1016/0304-4165(76)90376-7 }}</ref> who produced a successful MFC design a year later.<ref>{{Cite journal |first1=Isao |last1=Karube |first2=Tadashi |last2=Matsunaga |first3=Shinya |last3=Tsuru |first4=Shuichi |last4=Suzuki |date=November 1977 |title=Biochemical cells utilizing immobilized cells of ''Clostridium butyricum'' |journal=Biotechnology and Bioengineering |volume=19 |issue=11 |pages=1727–1733 |doi=10.1002/bit.260191112}}</ref>
In the late 1970s little was understood about how microbial fuel cells functioned. The idea was studied by Robin M. Allen and later by H. Peter Bennetto. People saw the fuel cell as a possible method for the generation of electricity for developing countries. Bennetto's work, starting in the early 1980s, helped build an understanding of how fuel cells operate and he was seen by many{{Who|date=April 2011}} as the topic's foremost authority.
In May 2007, the [[University of Queensland]], Australia completed a prototype MFC as a cooperative effort with [[Foster's Group|Foster's Brewing]]. The prototype, a 10 L design, converted [[brewery wastewater]] into carbon dioxide, clean water and electricity. The group had plans to create a pilot-scale model for an upcoming international bio-energy conference.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brewing a sustainable energy solution|url=http://www.uq.edu.au/news/article/2007/05/brewing-sustainable-energy-solution|website=The University of Queensland Australia|accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref>
==Definition== A microbial fuel cell (MFC) is a device that [[energy conversion|converts]] [[chemical energy]] to [[electrical energy]] by the action of [[microorganisms]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Allen |first1=R.M. |last2=Bennetto |first2=H.P. |year=1993 |title=Microbial fuel cells: Electricity production from carbohydrates |journal=Applied Biochemistry and Biotechnology |volume=39–40 |pages=27–40 |doi=10.1007/bf02918975}}</ref> These electrochemical cells are constructed using either a bioanode and/or a biocathode. Most MFCs contain a membrane to separate the compartments of the anode (where oxidation takes place) and the cathode (where reduction takes place). The electrons produced during oxidation are transferred directly to an electrode or, to a [[redox]] mediator species. The electron flux is moved to the cathode. The charge balance of the system is compensated by ionic movement inside the cell, usually across an iconic membrane. Most MFCs use an organic [[electron donor]] that is oxidized to produce CO<sub>2</sub>, protons and electrons. Other electron donors have been reported, such as sulphur compounds or hydrogen.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Pant | first1 = D. | last2 = Van Bogaert | first2 = G. | last3 = Diels | first3 = L. | last4 = Vanbroekhoven | first4 = K. | year = 2010 | title = A review of the substrates used in microbial fuel cells (MFCs) for sustainable energy production | url = | journal = Bioresource Technology | volume = 101 | issue = 6| pages = 1533–43 | doi = 10.1016/j.biortech.2009.10.017 | pmid=19892549}}</ref> The cathode reaction uses a variety of electron acceptors that includes the reduction of oxygen as the most studied process. However, other electron acceptors have been studied, including metal recovery by reduction,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lu | first1 = Z. | last2 = Chang | first2 = D. | last3 = Ma | first3 = J. | last4 = Huang | first4 = G. | last5 = Cai | first5 = L. | last6 = Zhang | first6 = L. | year = 2015 | title = Behavior of metal ions in bioelectrochemical systems: A review | url = | journal = Journal of Power Sources | volume = 275 | issue = | pages = 243–260 | doi = 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2014.10.168 }}</ref> water to hydrogen,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Oh | first1 = S. | last2 = Logan | first2 = B. E. | year = 2005 | title = Hydrogen and electricity production from a food processing wastewater using fermentation and microbial fuel cell technologies | url = | journal = Water Research | volume = 39 | issue = 19| pages = 4673–4682 | doi = 10.1016/j.watres.2005.09.019 }}</ref> nitrate reduction and sulfate reduction.
== Applications ==
===Power generation=== MFCs are attractive for power generation applications that require only low power, but where replacing batteries may be impractical, such as wireless sensor networks.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-642-36365-8_6|title=Wireless Sensor Networks and Ecological Monitoring|volume=3|publisher=Springer link|year=2013|isbn=978-3-642-36365-8|pages=151–178|author1=Subhas C Mukhopadhyay|author2=Joe-Air Jiang|doi=10.1007/978-3-642-36365-8_6|chapter=Application of Microbial Fuel Cells to Power Sensor Networks for Ecological Monitoring|series=Smart Sensors, Measurement and Instrumentation}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.biortech.2013.12.078 |pmid=24434696 |title=A stable synergistic microbial consortium for simultaneous azo dye removal and bioelectricity generation |journal=Bioresource Technology |volume=155 |pages=71–6 |year=2014 |last1=Wang |first1=Victor Bochuan |last2=Chua |first2=Song-Lin |last3=Cai |first3=Zhao |last4=Sivakumar |first4=Krishnakumar |last5=Zhang |first5=Qichun |last6=Kjelleberg |first6=Staffan |last7=Cao |first7=Bin |last8=Loo |first8=Say Chye Joachim |last9=Yang |first9=Liang }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0063129 |pmid=23700414 |pmc=3659106 |title=Engineering PQS Biosynthesis Pathway for Enhancement of Bioelectricity Production in Pseudomonas aeruginosa Microbial Fuel Cells |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=8 |issue=5 |pages=e63129 |year=2013 |last1=Wang |first1=Victor Bochuan |last2=Chua |first2=Song-Lin |last3=Cao |first3=Bin |last4=Seviour |first4=Thomas |last5=Nesatyy |first5=Victor J |last6=Marsili |first6=Enrico |last7=Kjelleberg |first7=Staffan |last8=Givskov |first8=Michael |last9=Tolker-Nielsen |first9=Tim |last10=Song |first10=Hao |last11=Loo |first11=Joachim Say Chye |last12=Yang |first12=Liang }}</ref>
Virtually any organic material could be used to feed the fuel cell, including coupling cells to [[wastewater treatment plant]]s. Chemical process wastewater<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.fuel.2008.03.002 |title=Harnessing of bioelectricity in microbial fuel cell (MFC) employing aerated cathode through anaerobic treatment of chemical wastewater using selectively enriched hydrogen producing mixed consortia |journal=Fuel |volume=87 |issue=12 |pages=2667–76 |year=2008 |last1=Venkata Mohan |first1=S |last2=Mohanakrishna |first2=G |last3=Srikanth |first3=S |last4=Sarma |first4=P.N }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.bej.2007.08.023 |title=Bioelectricity generation from chemical wastewater treatment in mediatorless (anode) microbial fuel cell (MFC) using selectively enriched hydrogen producing mixed culture under acidophilic microenvironment |journal=Biochemical Engineering Journal |volume=39 |pages=121–30 |year=2008 |last1=Venkata Mohan |first1=S |last2=Mohanakrishna |first2=G |last3=Reddy |first3=B. Purushotham |last4=Saravanan |first4=R |last5=Sarma |first5=P.N }}</ref> and synthetic wastewater<ref>{{cite journal |first1=S. Venkata |last1=Mohan |first2=S. |last2=Veer Raghavulu |first3=S. |last3=Srikanth |first4=P. N. |last4=Sarma |title=Bioelectricity production by mediatorless microbial fuel cell under acidophilic condition using wastewater as substrate: Influence of substrate loading rate |journal=Current Science |volume=92 |issue=12 |date=25 June 2007 |pages=1720–6 |jstor=24107621 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.biortech.2006.12.026 |pmid=17321135 |title=Bioelectricity production from wastewater treatment in dual chambered microbial fuel cell (MFC) using selectively enriched mixed microflora: Effect of catholyte |journal=Bioresource Technology |volume=99 |issue=3 |pages=596–603 |year=2008 |last1=Venkata Mohan |first1=S |last2=Saravanan |first2=R |last3=Raghavulu |first3=S. Veer |last4=Mohanakrishna |first4=G |last5=Sarma |first5=P.N }}</ref> have been used to produce bioelectricity in dual- and single-chamber mediatorless MFCs (uncoated graphite electrodes).
Higher power production was observed with a [[biofilm]]-covered graphite [[anode]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.bios.2007.11.016 |pmid=18248978 |title=Biochemical evaluation of bioelectricity production process from anaerobic wastewater treatment in a single chambered microbial fuel cell (MFC) employing glass wool membrane |journal=Biosensors and Bioelectronics |volume=23 |issue=9 |pages=1326–32 |year=2008 |last1=Venkata Mohan |first1=S |last2=Veer Raghavulu |first2=S |last3=Sarma |first3=P.N }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.bios.2008.03.010 |pmid=18440217 |title=Influence of anodic biofilm growth on bioelectricity production in single chambered mediatorless microbial fuel cell using mixed anaerobic consortia |journal=Biosensors and Bioelectronics |volume=24 |issue=1 |pages=41–7 |year=2008 |last1=Venkata Mohan |first1=S |last2=Veer Raghavulu |first2=S |last3=Sarma |first3=P.N }}</ref> Fuel cell emissions are well under regulatory limits.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Choi |first1=Y. |last2=Jung |first2=S. |last3=Kim |first3=S. |year=2000 |title=Development of Microbial Fuel Cells Using Proteus Vulgaris Bulletin of the Korean Chemical Society |volume=21 |issue=1 |pages=44–8 }}</ref> MFCs use energy more efficiently than standard [[internal combustion engine]]s, which are limited by the [[Carnot Cycle]]. In theory, an MFC is capable of energy efficiency far beyond 50%.<ref>Yue & Lowther, 1986</ref> Rozendal obtained energy conversion to hydrogen 8 times that of conventional hydrogen production technologies.
However; MFCs can also work at a smaller scale. Electrodes in some cases need only be 7 μm thick by 2 cm long.<ref>{{Cite journal|last2=Barton|first2=S.C.|last3=Binyamin|first3=G.|last4=Gao|first4=Z.|last5=Zhang|first5=Y.|last6=Kim|first6=H.-H.|last7=Heller|first7=A.|date=Sep 2001|title=A miniature biofuel cell.|journal=J Am Chem Soc|volume=123|issue=35|pages=8630–1|doi=10.1021/ja0163164|pmid=11525685|last1=Chen|first1=T.}}</ref> such that an MFC can replace a battery. It provides a renewable form of energy and does not need to be recharged.
MFCs operate well in mild conditions, 20 °C to 40 °C and also at [[pH]] of around 7.<ref name="pmid16569499">{{cite journal|year=2006|title=Biofuel cells and their development.|journal=Biosensors & Bioelectronics|volume=21|issue=11|pages=2015–45|doi=10.1016/j.bios.2006.01.030|pmid=16569499|vauthors=Bullen RA, Arnot TC, Lakeman JB, Walsh FC}}</ref> They lack the stability required for long-term medical applications such as in [[artificial pacemaker|pacemakers]].
Power stations can be based on aquatic plants such as algae. If sited adjacent to an existing power system, the MFC system can share its electricity lines.<ref>Eos magazine, Waterstof uit het riool, June 2008</ref>
===Education=== Soil-based microbial fuel cells serve as educational tools, as they encompass multiple scientific disciplines (microbiology, geochemistry, electrical engineering, etc.) and can be made using commonly available materials, such as soils and items from the refrigerator. Kits for home science projects and classrooms are available.<ref name="MudWatt" /> One example of microbial fuel cells being used in the classroom is in the IBET (Integrated Biology, English, and Technology) curriculum for [[Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology]]. Several educational videos and articles are also available on the '''International Society for Microbial Electrochemistry and Technology''' (ISMET Society)"<ref>[https://www.is-met.org/]</ref>".
===Biosensor=== {{Main|Biosensor}}
The current generated from a microbial fuel cell is directly proportional to the energy content of wastewater used as the fuel. MFCs can measure the solute concentration of wastewater (i.e., as a [[biosensor]]).<ref>{{Cite journal|last2=Chang|first2=IS.|last3=Gil|first3=GC.|last4=Park|first4=HS.|last5=Kim|first5=HJ.|date=April 2003|title=Novel BOD (biological oxygen demand) sensor using mediator-less microbial fuel cell|journal=Biotechnology Letters|volume=25|issue=7|pages=541–545|doi=10.1023/A:1022891231369|last1=Kim|first1=BH.|pmid=12882142}}</ref>
Wastewater is commonly assessed for its [[biochemical oxygen demand]] (BOD) values.{{Clarify|date=April 2011}} BOD values are determined by incubating samples for 5 days with proper source of microbes, usually activated sludge collected from wastewater plants.
An MFC-type BOD sensor can provide real-time BOD values. Oxygen and nitrate are preferred electron acceptors over the electrode, reducing current generation from an MFC. MFC BOD sensors underestimate BOD values in the presence of these electron acceptors. This can be avoided by inhibiting aerobic and nitrate respiration in the MFC using terminal oxidase inhibitors such as [[cyanide]] and [[azide]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.bios.2004.06.003 |pmid=15681205 |title=Improvement of a microbial fuel cell performance as a BOD sensor using respiratory inhibitors |journal=Biosensors and Bioelectronics |volume=20 |issue=9 |pages=1856–9 |year=2005 |last1=Chang |first1=In Seop |last2=Moon |first2=Hyunsoo |last3=Jang |first3=Jae Kyung |last4=Kim |first4=Byung Hong }}</ref> Such BOD sensors are commercially available.
The [[United States Navy]] is considering microbial fuel cells for environmental sensors. The use of microbial fuel cells to power environmental sensors would be able to provide power for longer periods and enable the collection and retrieval of undersea data without a wired infrastructure. The energy created by these fuel cells is enough to sustain the sensors after an initial startup time.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2011|title=Benthic Microbial Fuel Cell as Direct Power Source for an Acoustic Modem and Seawater Oxygen/Temperature Sensor System|journal=Environmental Science and Technology|volume=45|issue=11|pages=5047–53|doi=10.1021/es104383q|pmid=21545151|author=Gong, Y., Radachowsky, S. E., Wolf, M., Nielsen, M. E., Girguis, P. R., & Reimers, C. E.}}</ref> Due to undersea conditions (high salt concentrations, fluctuating temperatures and limited nutrient supply), the Navy may deploy MFCs with a mixture of salt-tolerant microorganisms. A mixture would allow for a more complete utilization of available nutrients. ''[[Shewanella oneidensis]]'' is their primary candidate, but may include other heat- and cold-tolerant ''Shewanella spp''.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2008|title=Aerobic Miniature Microbial Fuel Cells|journal=NRL Review|pages=141–42|author=Biffinger, J.C., Little, B., Pietron, J., Ray, R., Ringeisen, B.R.}}</ref>
A first self-powered and autonomous BOD/COD biosensor has been developed and allows to detect organic contaminants in freshwater. The senor relies only on power produced by MFCs and operates continuously without maintenance. The biosensor turns on the alarm to inform about contamination level: the increased frequency of the signal informs about higher contamination level, while low frequency warns about low contamination level.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-06-01|title=Self-powered, autonomous Biological Oxygen Demand biosensor for online water quality monitoring|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925400517300199|journal=Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical|language=en|volume=244|pages=815–822|doi=10.1016/j.snb.2017.01.019|issn=0925-4005}}</ref>
===Biorecovery=== In 2010, A. ter Heijne et al.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/es100526g |title=Copper Recovery Combined with Electricity Production in a Microbial Fuel Cell |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |volume=44 |issue=11 |pages=4376–81 |year=2010 |last1=Heijne |first1=Annemiek Ter |last2=Liu |first2=Fei |last3=Weijden |first3=Renata van der |last4=Weijma |first4=Jan |last5=Buisman |first5=Cees J.N |last6=Hamelers |first6=Hubertus V.M }}</ref> constructed a device capable of producing electricity and reducing Cu (II) (ion) to copper metal.
Microbial electrolysis cells have been demonstrated to produce hydrogen.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s00253-012-4456-7 |pmid=23053105 |title=Production of hydrogen from domestic wastewater in a pilot-scale microbial electrolysis cell |journal=Applied Microbiology and Biotechnology |volume=97 |issue=15 |pages=6979–89 |year=2012 |last1=Heidrich |first1=E. S |last2=Dolfing |first2=J |last3=Scott |first3=K |last4=Edwards |first4=S. R |last5=Jones |first5=C |last6=Curtis |first6=T. P }}</ref>
===Wastewater treatment===
MFCs are used in water treatment to harvest energy utilizing [[anaerobic digestion]]. The process can also reduce pathogens. However, it requires temperatures upwards of 30 degrees C and requires an extra step in order to convert [[biogas]] to electricity. Spiral spacers may be used to increase electricity generation by creating a helical flow in the MFC. Scaling MFCs is a challenge because of the power output challenges of a larger surface area.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2013|title=Using Microbial Fuel Cells to Treat Raw Sludge and Primary Effluent for Bioelectricity Generation|journal=Department of Civil Engineering and Mechanics; University of Wisconsin - Milwaukee|author=Zhang, Fei, He, Zhen, Ge, Zheng}}</ref>
==Types==
===Mediated=== Most microbial cells are electrochemically inactive. Electron transfer from microbial cells to the [[electrode]] is facilitated by mediators such as [[thionin]]e, [[methyl viologen]], [[methyl blue]], [[humic acid]] and [[neutral red]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Delaney | first1 = G. M. | last2 = Bennetto | first2 = H. P. | last3 = Mason | first3 = J. R. | last4 = Roller | first4 = S. D. | last5 = Stirling | first5 = J. L. | last6 = Thurston | first6 = C. F. | doi = 10.1002/jctb.280340104 | title = Electron-transfer coupling in microbial fuel cells. 2. Performance of fuel cells containing selected microorganism-mediator-substrate combinations | journal = Journal of Chemical Technology and Biotechnology. Biotechnology | volume = 34 | pages = 13–27 | year = 2008 }}</ref><ref>Lithgow, A.M., Romero, L., Sanchez, I.C., Souto, F.A., and Vega, C.A. (1986). Interception of electron-transport chain in bacteria with hydrophilic redox mediators. ''J. Chem. Research,'' (S):178–179.</ref> Most available mediators are expensive and toxic.
===Mediator-free === [[File:Plant Microbial Fuel Cell.png|thumb|left|250px|A plant microbial fuel cell (PMFC)]] Mediator-free microbial fuel cells use electrochemically active bacteria to transfer electrons to the electrode (electrons are carried directly from the bacterial respiratory enzyme to the electrode). Among the electrochemically active bacteria are ''[[Shewanella putrefaciens]]'',<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kim | first1 = B.H. | last2 = Kim | first2 = H.J. | last3 = Hyun | first3 = M.S. | last4 = Park | first4 = D.H. | year = 1999a | title = ''Direct electrode reaction of Fe (III) reducing bacterium, ''Shewanella putrefacience | url = http://bioelectrochemistry.kist.re.kr/downloads/pdf/1-5.pdf | format = PDF | journal = J Microbiol Biotechnol | volume = 9 | issue = | pages = 127–131 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040908164327/http://bioelectrochemistry.kist.re.kr/downloads/pdf/1-5.pdf | archivedate = 2004-09-08 | df = }}</ref> ''[[Aeromonas hydrophila]]''<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Pham | first1 = C. A. | last2 = Jung | first2 = S. J. | last3 = Phung | first3 = N. T. | last4 = Lee | first4 = J. | last5 = Chang | first5 = I. S. | last6 = Kim | first6 = B. H. | last7 = Yi | first7 = H. | last8 = Chun | first8 = J. | doi = 10.1016/S0378-1097(03)00354-9 | title = A novel electrochemically active and Fe(III)-reducing bacterium phylogenetically related to Aeromonas hydrophila, isolated from a microbial fuel cell | journal = FEMS Microbiology Letters | volume = 223 | issue = 1 | pages = 129–134 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12799011 }}</ref> and others. Some bacteria are able to transfer their electron production via the [[Pilus|pili]] on their external membrane. Mediator-free MFCs are less well characterized, such as the [[strain (biology)|strain]] of bacteria used in the system, type of [[ion-exchange membrane]] and system conditions (temperature, pH, etc.)
Mediator-free microbial fuel cells can run on [[wastewater]] and derive energy directly from certain plants. This configuration is known as a plant microbial fuel cell. Possible plants include [[Glyceria maxima|reed sweetgrass]], [[Spartina|cordgrass]], rice, tomatoes, [[Lupinus|lupines]] and [[algae]].<ref>[http://www.plantpower.eu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3&Itemid=4 Mediator-less microbial fuel cell schematic + explanation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310220311/http://www.plantpower.eu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3&Itemid=4 |date=March 10, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ete.wur.nl/UK/Research/Renewable+Energy/Green+electricity+production+by+living+plants+in+a+microbial+fuel+cell/|title=Environmental Technology|work=Wageningen UR}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/er.1397 |title=Green electricity production with living plants and bacteria in a fuel cell |journal=[[International Journal of Energy Research]] |volume=32 |issue=9 |pages=870–6 |year=2008 |last1=Strik |first1=David P. B. T. B |last2=Hamelers (Bert) |first2=H. V. M |last3=Snel |first3=Jan F. H |last4=Buisman |first4=Cees J. N }}</ref> Given that the power is derived from living plants (''in situ''-energy production), this variant can provide ecological advantages.
===Microbial electrolysis === {{Main|Microbial electrolysis cell}} One variation of the mediator-less MFC is the microbial electrolysis cell (MEC). While MFCs produce electric current by the bacterial decomposition of organic compounds in water, MECs partially reverse the process to generate hydrogen or methane by applying a voltage to bacteria. This supplements the voltage generated by the microbial decomposition of organics, leading to the [[electrolysis of water]] or methane production.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.awmc.uq.edu.au/index.html?page=84198|title=Advanced Water Management Centre|work=Advanced Water Management Centre}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytech.com/Microbial+Hydrogen+Production+Threatens+Extinction+for+the+Ethanol+Dinosaur/article9278.htm|title=DailyTech - Microbial Hydrogen Production Threatens Extinction for the Ethanol Dinosaur|publisher=}}</ref> A complete reversal of the MFC principle is found in [[microbial electrosynthesis]], in which [[carbon dioxide]] is reduced by bacteria using an external electric current to form multi-carbon organic compounds.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://mbio.asm.org/content/1/2/e00103-10.full |title=Microbial Electrosynthesis: Feeding Microbes Electricity To Convert Carbon Dioxide and Water to Multicarbon Extracellular Organic Compounds |doi=10.1128/mBio.00103-10 |date=May–June 2010 |author1=Nevin Kelly P. |author2=Woodard Trevor L. |author3=Franks Ashley E. |journal=MBio |volume=1 |issue=2|display-authors=etal |pages=e00103–10 |pmid=20714445 |pmc=2921159}}</ref>
===Soil-based=== [[File:SoilMFC.png|thumb|right|150px|A soil-based MFC]] [[Soil]]-based microbial fuel cells adhere to the basic MFC principles, whereby soil acts as the nutrient-rich anodic media, the [[inoculum]] and the [[proton exchange membrane]] (PEM). The [[anode]] is placed at a particular depth within the soil, while the [[cathode]] rests on top the soil and is exposed to air.
Soils naturally [[soil biology|teem with diverse microbes]], including electrogenic bacteria needed for MFCs, and are full of complex sugars and other nutrients that have accumulated from plant and animal material decay. Moreover, the [[aerobic organism|aerobic]] (oxygen consuming) microbes present in the soil act as an oxygen filter, much like the expensive PEM materials used in laboratory MFC systems, which cause the [[redox]] potential of the soil to decrease with greater depth. Soil-based MFCs are becoming popular educational tools for science classrooms.<ref name="MudWatt">{{cite web|url=http://www.magicalmicrobes.com/collections/kits/products/mudwatt-clean-energy-from-mud|title=MudWatt Science Kit|author=MudWatt|work=MudWatt}}</ref>
Sediment microbial fuel cells (SMFCs) have been applied for [[wastewater treatment]]. Simple SMFCs can generate energy while decontaminating [[wastewater]]. Most such SMFCs contain plants to mimic constructed wetlands. By 2015 SMFC tests had reached more than 150 l.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1039/C5EW00020C |title=Sediment microbial fuel cells for wastewater treatment: Challenges and opportunities |journal=Environmental Science: Water Research & Technology |volume=1 |issue=3 |pages=279–84 |year=2015 |last1=Xu |first1=Bojun |last2=Ge |first2=Zheng |last3=He |first3=Zhen |url=https://vtechworks.lib.vt.edu/bitstream/10919/64969/1/2015_Xu_Sediment_microbial_fuel_cells_for_wast.pdf }}</ref>
In 2015 researchers announced an SMFC application that extracts energy and charges a [[battery (electricity)|battery]]. Salts dissociate into positively and negatively charged ions in water and move and adhere to the respective negative and positive electrodes, charging the battery and making it possible to remove the salt effecting ''microbial capacitive [[desalination]]''. The microbes produce more energy than is required for the desalination process.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cleaning up wastewater from oil and gas operations using a microbe-powered battery |first= Helen |last=Clark |date=March 2, 2015 |publisher=Gizmag}}</ref>
===Phototrophic biofilm=== Phototrophic biofilm MFCs (ner) use a phototrophic [[biofilm]] anode containing photosynthetic microorganism such as [[chlorophyta]],[[Cyanobacteria|candyanophyta]].They carry out photosynthesis and thus produce organic metabolites and donate electrons.<ref>{{cite journal |last1 = Elizabeth |first1 = Elmy |url = http://www.biosaints.com/archives/vol1/vol1_3/microbial_fuelcells.html |title = GENERATING ELECTRICITY BY "NATURE’S WAY" |magazine = SALT 'B' online magazine |volume = 1 |year = 2012 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130118060508/http://www.biosaints.com/archives/vol1/vol1_3/microbial_fuelcells.html |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |df = }}</ref>
One study found that PBMFCs display a [[power density]] sufficient for practical applications.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.tibtech.2010.10.001 |pmid=21067833 |title=Microbial solar cells: Applying photosynthetic and electrochemically active organisms |journal=Trends in Biotechnology |volume=29 |issue=1 |pages=41–9 |year=2011 |last1=Strik |first1=David P.B.T.B |last2=Timmers |first2=Ruud A |last3=Helder |first3=Marjolein |last4=Steinbusch |first4=Kirsten J.J |last5=Hamelers |first5=Hubertus V.M |last6=Buisman |first6=Cees J.N }}</ref>
The sub-category of phototrophic MFCs that use purely oxygenic photosynthetic material at the anode are sometimes called [[biological photovoltaics|biological photovoltaic]] systems.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1039/c1ee02531g |title=Quantitative analysis of the factors limiting solar power transduction by Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 in biological photovoltaic devices |journal=Energy & Environmental Science |volume=4 |issue=11 |pages=4690–8 |year=2011 |last1=Bombelli |first1=Paolo |last2=Bradley |first2=Robert W |last3=Scott |first3=Amanda M |last4=Philips |first4=Alexander J |last5=McCormick |first5=Alistair J |last6=Cruz |first6=Sonia M |last7=Anderson |first7=Alexander |last8=Yunus |first8=Kamran |last9=Bendall |first9=Derek S |last10=Cameron |first10=Petra J |last11=Davies |first11=Julia M |last12=Smith |first12=Alison G |last13=Howe |first13=Christopher J |last14=Fisher |first14=Adrian C }}</ref>
===Nanoporous membrane=== The [[United States Naval Research Laboratory]] developed nanoporous membrane microbial fuel cells that use a non-PEM to generate passive diffusion within the cell.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrl.navy.mil/techtransfer/available-technologies/energy/miniature-microbial-fuel-cells |title=Miniature Microbial Fuel Cells |website=Technology Transfer Office |accessdate=30 November 2014}}</ref> The membrane is a nonporous polymer filter ([[nylon]], [[cellulose]], or [[polycarbonate]]). It offers comparable power densities to [[Nafion]] (a well known PEM) with greater durability. Porous membranes allow passive diffusion thereby reducing the necessary power supplied to the MFC in order to keep the PEM active and increasing the total energy output.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Biffinger |first=Justin C. |last2=Ray |first2=Ricky |last3=Little |first3=Brenda |last4=Ringeisen |first4=Bradley R. |year=2007 |title=Diversifying Biological Fuel Cell Design by Use of Nanoporous Filters |journal=Environmental Science and Technology |volume=41 |issue=4 |pages=1444–49 |doi=10.1021/es061634u }}</ref>
MFCs that do not use a membrane can deploy anaerobic bacteria in aerobic environments. However, membrane-less MFCs experience cathode contamination by the indigenous bacteria and the power-supplying microbe. The novel passive diffusion of nanoporous membranes can achieve the benefits of a membrane-less MFC without worry of cathode contamination.
Nanoporous membranes are also eleven times cheaper than Nafion (Nafion-117, $0.22/cm<sup>2</sup> vs. polycarbonate, <$0.02/cm<sup>2</sup>).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.slideshare.net/ShabeebaVAnthru/seminar-2-56681944|title=Seminar 2|last=Shabeeba|first=Anthru|date=5 Jan 2016|website=Slide Share|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
===Ceramic membrane=== PEM membranes can be replaced with ceramic materials. [[Ceramic membrane]] costs can be as low as $5.66 /m<sup>2</sup>. The macroporous structure of ceramic membranes allows good transport of ionic species.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/cssc.201501320 |pmid=26692569 |pmc=4744959 |title=Comprehensive Study on Ceramic Membranes for Low-Cost Microbial Fuel Cells |journal=ChemSusChem |volume=9 |issue=1 |pages=88–96 |year=2016 |last1=Pasternak |first1=Grzegorz |last2=Greenman |first2=John |last3=Ieropoulos |first3=Ioannis }}</ref>
The materials that have been successfully employed in ceramic MFCs are [[earthenware]], [[Aluminium oxide|alumina]], [[mullite]], [[pyrophyllite]] and [[terracotta]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.biortech.2009.07.089 |pmid=19800223 |title=Performance evaluation of low cost microbial fuel cell fabricated using earthen pot with biotic and abiotic cathode |journal=Bioresource Technology |volume=101 |issue=4 |pages=1183–9 |year=2010 |last1=Behera |first1=Manaswini |last2=Jana |first2=Partha S |last3=Ghangrekar |first3=M.M }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s00449-013-0967-6 |pmid=23728836 |title=Comparing terracotta and earthenware for multiple functionalities in microbial fuel cells |journal=Bioprocess and Biosystems Engineering |volume=36 |issue=12 |pages=1913–21 |year=2013 |last1=Winfield |first1=Jonathan |last2=Greenman |first2=John |last3=Huson |first3=David |last4=Ieropoulos |first4=Ioannis }}</ref>
==Generation process== When microorganisms consume a substance such as [[sugar]] in aerobic conditions, they produce [[carbon dioxide]] and [[water]]. However, when [[oxygen]] is not present, they produce carbon dioxide, [[proton]]s[[Hydrogen ion|/hydrogen ions]] and [[electron]]s, as described below:<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.ncbe.reading.ac.uk/ncbe/protocols/PRACBIOTECH/PDF/bennetto.pdf |last=Bennetto |first=H. P. |year=1990 |title=Electricity Generation by Micro-organisms |journal=Biotechnology Education |volume=1 |number=4 |pages=163–168}}<!-- multiple other PDF sources available as of July 2012; search Google Scholar if this link dies --></ref>
C<sub>12</sub>H<sub>22</sub>O<sub>11</sub> + 13H<sub>2</sub>O → 12CO<sub>2</sub> + 48H<sup>+</sup> + 48e<sup>−</sup> (''Eqt. 1'')
Microbial fuel cells use [[inorganic]] mediators to tap into the [[electron transport chain]] of cells and channel electrons produced. The mediator crosses the outer cell [[lipid membranes]] and [[bacterial outer membrane]]; then, it begins to liberate electrons from the electron transport chain that normally would be taken up by oxygen or other intermediates.
The now-reduced mediator exits the cell laden with electrons that it transfers to an electrode; this electrode becomes the anode. The release of the electrons recycles the mediator to its original oxidised state, ready to repeat the process. '''This can happen only under anaerobic conditions'''; if oxygen is present, it will collect the electrons, as it has greater [[electronegativity]].
In MFC operation, the anode is the terminal electron acceptor recognized by bacteria in the anodic chamber. Therefore, the microbial activity is strongly dependent on the anode's redox potential. A [[Michaelis-Menten]] curve was obtained between the anodic potential and the power output of an [[acetate]]-driven MFC. A critical anodic potential seems to provide maximum power output.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/es8003969 |pmid=18546730 |title=Affinity of Microbial Fuel Cell Biofilm for the Anodic Potential |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |volume=42 |issue=10 |pages=3828–34 |year=2008 |last1=Cheng |first1=Ka Yu |last2=Ho |first2=Goen |last3=Cord-Ruwisch |first3=Ralf }}</ref>
Potential mediators include natural red, methylene blue, thionine and resorufin.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/bit.260250219 |pmid=18548670 |title=Anodic reactions in microbial fuel cells |journal=Biotechnology and Bioengineering |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=559–68 |year=1983 |last1=Bennetto |first1=H. Peter |last2=Stirling |first2=John L |last3=Tanaka |first3=Kazuko |last4=Vega |first4=Carmen A }}</ref>
Organisms capable of producing an electric current are termed [[exoelectrogen]]s. In order to turn this current into usable electricity, exoelectrogens have to be accommodated in a fuel cell.
The mediator and a micro-organism such as yeast, are mixed together in a solution to which is added a substrate such as [[glucose]]. This mixture is placed in a sealed chamber to stop oxygen entering, thus forcing the micro-organism to undertake [[anaerobic respiration]]. An electrode is placed in the solution to act as the anode.
In the second chamber of the MFC is another solution and the positively charged cathode. It is the equivalent of the oxygen sink at the end of the electron transport chain, external to the biological cell. The solution is an [[oxidizing agent]] that picks up the electrons at the cathode. As with the electron chain in the yeast cell, this could be a variety of molecules such as oxygen, although a more convenient option is a solid oxidizing agent, which requires less volume.
Connecting the two electrodes is a wire (or other electrically conductive path). Completing the circuit and connecting the two chambers is a salt bridge or ion-exchange membrane. This last feature allows the protons produced, as described in ''Eqt. 1,'' to pass from the anode chamber to the cathode chamber.
The reduced mediator carries electrons from the cell to the electrode. Here the mediator is oxidized as it deposits the electrons. These then flow across the wire to the second electrode, which acts as an electron sink. From here they pass to an oxidizing material. Also the hydrogen ions/protons are moved from the anode to the cathode via a proton exchange membrane such as [[nafion]]. They will move across to the lower concentration gradient and be combined with the oxygen but to do this they need an electron. This forms current and the hydrogen is used sustaining the concentration gradient.
Algae Biomass has been observed to give high energy when used as substrates in microbial fuel cell.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.scitotenv.2013.03.067 |pmid=23584037 |title=Enhanced electricity generation by using algae biomass and activated sludge in microbial fuel cell |journal=Science of the Total Environment |volume=456-457 |pages=91–4 |year=2013 |last1=Rashid |first1=Naim |last2=Cui |first2=Yu-Feng |last3=Saif Ur Rehman |first3=Muhammad |last4=Han |first4=Jong-In }}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Energy|Renewable energy|Sustainable development}} *[[Fermentative hydrogen production]] *[[Biobattery]] *[[Dark fermentation]] *[[Glossary of fuel cell terms]] *[[Photofermentation]] *[[Electrohydrogenesis]] *[[Electromethanogenesis]] *[[Hydrogen technologies]] *[[Hydrogen hypothesis]]

*{{cite web |author = The Biotech/Life Sciences Portal |date = 20 Jan 2006 |title = Impressive idea – self-sufficient fuel cells |url = http://www.bio-pro.de/magazin/wissenschaft/archiv_2006/index.html?lang=en&artikelid=/artikel/03009/index.html |publisher = Baden-Württemberg GmbH |accessdate = 2011-02-07 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110721035054/http://www.bio-pro.de/magazin/wissenschaft/archiv_2006/index.html?lang=en&artikelid=%2Fartikel%2F03009%2Findex.html |archivedate = 2011-07-21 |df = }}
* {{cite journal |vauthors=Liu H, Cheng S, Logan BE |year=2005 |title=Production of electricity from acetate or butyrate using a single-chamber microbial fuel cell |journal=Environ Sci Technol |volume=32 |issue=2 |pages=658–62 |doi=10.1021/es048927c }}
*{{cite journal |author1=Rabaey, K. |author2=W. Verstraete |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2005 |title=Microbial fuel cells: novel biotechnology for energy generations |journal=Trends Biotechnol |volume=23 |pages=291–298 |doi=10.1016/j.tibtech.2005.04.008 |pmid=15922081 |issue=6 }}
